data.title: Q&A: Burt Reynolds
data.meta_description: ‘To whom would I most like to say sorry? Dozens of women – I think you’ll figure out why’
data.text:
Born in Georgia, Burt Reynolds, 79, is best known for his action films Deliverance, Smokey And The Bandit and The Cannonball Run, and for his Golden Globe-winning role in the 1997 movie Boogie Nights. He had relationships with Sally Field and the late Dinah Shore, and is divorced from Loni Anderson, with whom he has a son. His new memoir, But Enough About Me, has just been published and he appears at a Guardian Live event on 2 December.

When were you happiest?

When I was under contract to Universal Pictures in 1959, just before I got my role on Riverboat.

What is your greatest fear?

The next ache I get – I got hurt doing a lot of stunts and now I’m paying.

What is your earliest memory?

My dad going off to war in 1942.

Which living person do you most admire, and why?

My son Quinton. He’s working behind the scenes in the picture biz and he’s done it all on his own.

What is the trait you most deplore in yourself?

My inability to say no to people who ask me favours.

Property aside, what’s the most expensive thing you’ve bought?

A ring for my ex-wife, Loni.

What is your most treasured possession?

I just received the Richard Farnsworth Diamond Award from the Stuntmen’s Association: it is the highest honour I’ve received and better than an Oscar.

What would your superpower be?

What makes you think I don’t have any? But if I got another, I’d say flight.

What do you most dislike about your appearance?

My short legs.

Who would play you in the film of your life?

George Clooney.

Which book changed your life?

The Catcher In The Rye: I was shocked to find my fears and concerns about life were shared by others.

What did you want to be when you were growing up?

A football player, a coach, a teacher.

What makes you unhappy?

Losing friends. Too many have passed away.

What is top of your bucket list?

To play a role that surprises and shocks everyone – I have a few good ones in me still.

To whom would you most like to say sorry, and why?

Dozens of women – I think you’ll figure out why.

What or who is the greatest love of your life?

Miss Dinah Shore.

Which words or phrases do you most overuse?

“Don’t act – behave.” I say that a lot in the class that I teach – and the students listen.

What is the worst job you’ve done?

My dad got me a job for one summer harvesting sugarcane in Belle Glade, Florida – it was the most gruelling physical labour I’ve ever done.

If you could edit your past, what would you change?

I wouldn’t have done the naked centrefold in Cosmopolitan magazine in 1972.

If you could go back in time, where would you go?

Dodge City, Kansas, in the 1870s.

How often do you have sex?

Not often enough – or maybe it’s too often.

What song would you like played at your funeral?

The psalm would be the 23rd. I’ll have to think about the song.
